Award.AwardTitle: Micromechanics of Red Blood Cells in Sickle Cell Disease
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, the PI will model the entire healthy red blood cell (RBC) by introducing a coarse-grain molecular dynamics (CGMD) using a two-component membrane model for normal RBCs. The model will fully count for both the membrane skeleton and the phospholipid bilayer. The model will be expanded to simulate the entire healthy RBC. The characteristics of a quiescent healthy RBC, including its biconcave shape and material properties, will be obtained. In addition the PI will model sickle RBCs by creating a CGMD model for polymerized deoxygenated sickle hemoglobin (HbS) fibers and show how the interaction between HbS fibers and the membrane results to the biomechanical properties and to the variety of shapes of sickle RBCs via deformation, membrane loss and dehydration. The PI will also experimentally validate the model by employong AFM to measure local and average force displacement responses for normal and sickle RBCs from which the stiffness will be obtained. The average and local loss and storage moduli of normal and sickle RBCs will also be measured via active microrheology experiments. Simultaneously, the amount and the domains of polymerized HbS will be determined via an optical microscopy technique in the same cells where the mechanical properties are measured. The results of the CGMD simulations will be compared with the proposed single cell experiments to validate the model parameters. The outreach activities will promote engineering and science in high school teachers and students and in particular they will advance the participation of high school girls in science and technology. The educational program will promote the involvement of minority students in engineering and it will increase the interest of students in the multidisciplinary field of cell mechanics. The computational tools, the experimental setup, and the protocols will be available via a freely accessible website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sickle cell disease (SCD) is an inherited blood disorder caused by a single point mutation that results in the production of defective hemoglobin HbS. Deoxygenated HbS in red blood cells (RBCs) polymerizes forming stiff fibers, which force RBCs to assume non-biconcave and mostly sickle shapes. Moreover, deoxygenated RBCs become more viscous than normal RBCs. One of the important consequences of the change in the biomechanical properties of deoxygenated RBCs is that they interact with other RBCs, platelets, and the endothelium impeding blood flow and causing vasoocclusion and organ damage. In this project, we used experiments and simulations to investigate biomechanical properties of normal and SCD RBCs.

As a result of activities related to this grant, we have developed a particle-based model for sickle hemoglobin fibers to study their interactions. We also developed models for the RBC membrane that include explicit description of the lipid bilayer and the actin-spectrin membrane skeleton. We then used the membrane model to investigate the conditions under which the RBC loses its membrane through vesiculation. In addition to numerical simulations, we performed atomic force microscopy experiments and built a novel microfluidics setup with controlled environmental conditions to measure the static and dynamic stiffness as well as the viscosity of normal and SCD RBCs. We found that SCD RBCs are stiffer and more viscous than normal RBCs. We also built, and made freely available to the scientific community, the force review automation environment (FRAME) for expedited data processing of AFM experiments with a graphical user interface.

One PhD thesis, which has been published (Dr. He Li), and another one, which is expected to be approved by April of 2019 (Ms. Jing Zhang), are products of this work. The software FRAME is freely available to other investigators. We expect that the results will improve our understanding of the pathophysiology of SCD. The broader impacts of the project include the training of female high school and undergraduate UCONN students in microfluidics and in the principles of atomic force microscopy. We also familiarized large numbers of UCONN students in the freshman year with the pathophysiology of SCD.
